docs.snippet: A quick look back at last night's awards, a mix of tradition and a few curveballs....
docs.lead_paragraph: What is an outfit to do when it is confronted by all manner of movies with no runaway hit? Why not spread the hardware around? When the Bagger went to the Governor's Ball following the awards, he noticed that the Oscars were very evenly distributed about the room, as were the smiles.
docs.abstract: A quick look back at last night's awards, a mix of tradition and a few curveballs.

docs.snippet: Congratulations to Tilda Swinton and Marion Cotillard, who won top honors at last night's Academy Awards. Both ladies played leading roles on the cover of T Magazine and we couldn't be more proud of them. Ms. Cotillard won best actress for "La Vie...
docs.lead_paragraph: Congratulations to Tilda Swinton and Marion Cotillard, who won top honors at last night's Academy Awards. Both ladies played leading roles on the cover of T Magazine and we couldn't be more proud of them. Ms. Cotillard won best actress for "La Vie en Rose" and Ms. Swinton's role as a corporate climber in "Michael Clayton" paid off. Get caught up on Hollywood's new royalty: read T's profiles of this year's best actress and best supporting actress.

docs.snippet: Tilda Swinton could not be any more different that the doughy, sweaty character she plays in "Michael Clayton."...
docs.lead_paragraph: Tilda Swinton could not be any more different that the doughy, sweaty character she plays in "Michael Clayton." With a shock of red, short hair and a very thin draped in black velvet, she looked like a human exclamation point.
docs.abstract: Tilda Swinton could not be any more different that the doughy, sweaty character she plays in "Michael Clayton."

docs.snippet: The press room may be the worst place in the world to watch the Oscars, but the Bagger is beginning to notice a trend....
docs.lead_paragraph: The press room may be the worst place in the world to watch the Oscars, but the Bagger is beginning to notice a trend. Even though the strike lifted and the whole show is back on, Jon Stewart and the producers continue to insist on showing filmed segments that would have been broadcast, as if to menace the crowd with what might have been. Maybe it would have been worse, but for the time being, there seems to be an odd juxtaposition of hackery -- a filmed riff on telescopes and binoculars -- sentiment -- Jon Stewart going so sweet on the kids from "August Rush" -- and vamping -- pregger jokes about Cate Blanchett and Jessica Alba.
docs.abstract: The press room may be the worst place in the world to watch the Oscars, but the Bagger is beginning to notice a trend.
